Formal definition of Turing hard: blah blah blah hard blah blah Turing blah.
Wikipedia: Given a set X in P(N), a set A in N is called Turing hard for X if X <=_T A for all X in X. If additionally A is in X, then A is called Turing complete for X.
yeah, i think i'll have to put significant time into that, for me to comprehend it :)
but maybe i will, some day :P
My point is that people like to use mumbo jumbo to describe more concise mumbo jumbo.
E.g. A problem is NP-hard if it is at least as hard as all the problems in NP.

body.saying: so what the point of hashes, can't we just use void pointers to key/val ?
oilio: hashes as in hash tables?
oilio: they are one way to efficiently implement the dictionary Abstract Data Type (ADT).
oilio: a hash table can store more than one key , value pair.
yeah, I read about it in the wikipedia
oilio: and you can lookup a value based on a key efficiently.
Linear search is good enough for everyone.
indolf: what if the hole table wont fit in the memory?
well if no ram and no swap no allocation
We have the whole Internet for our tables.
ask reddit how that worked out
yea, I store all my data in /dev/null
oilio: then you'll need to use a more sophisticated (and slower) data structure that can offload to disk.
I use the Boost libraries for /dev/null too.
And I use async writes to /dev/null.
don't want to get into resource contention when using /dev/null
only so much null to go around

info.tagline: /dev/null - the ultra-fast solution for all your storage needs.

http://www.shlomifish.org/lecture/W2L/Development/slides/gcc/flags.html - heh, first Google hit for "gcc important flags"
doomrobo: OK, I did not originate that page originally.
doomrobo: and it served a certain purpose as material for slides to the Haifa Linux Club's Welcome to Linux series.
body.me_is: always found it funny that -Wall doesn't turn on all of the warnings
body.saying: (which really needs to be the name of a future Ubuntu release)
people reading this are probably just shaking their heads

does anyone happen to know what std::allocator.allocate() does when you try to allocate 0 bytes? I get a pointer back but I can't tell what it's pointing at and I can't seem to find anything on the web that gives a difinitive answer
Why are you allocating zero bytes?
tnzr: the same thing it always returns

GeDaMo: we are implementing our own allocator for an assignment, and when asked what we should do if the user tries to allocate 0 bytes, the prof said to find out what std::allocator does and mimic that
GeDaMo: zero bytes are enough to hold the Complete Works of Shakespeare.
Depends on how many monkeys you have to decompress it :P
Of course, I defined a custom decompressor that emits the complete works of Shakespeare on empty input and uses gzip compression otherwise.
redeemed: compress the decompressor using the same algo
0 bytes = a decompressor for the entire works of shakespeare
now i have to choose a precious stone for each day of the week, thanks
this is going to take half the night
i guess there's already a gemstone for every month, so this would be seen as kind of a ripoff
maybe a metal for every day
Either our mac server is sending out little electroshocks through his cage and into my foot or he is just vibrating really strange...
rindolf: jeh, we have a macserver running a vm with a ubuntu server
rindolf: Most people react like "what the...?!"
Zepo: next you'll tell me that you have an HP/UX Desktop.
rindolf: I am not that crazy, my chef made this...thing...

info.tagline: Using the right tool for the job

body.saying: rindolf: How long have you got on the book?
rindolf, did you check out the new game of thrones episode?
Jude: no, I don't watch Game of Thrones.
Jude: I did see this on Slashdot - http://yro.slashdot.org/story/13/03/31/1347248/hbo-says-game-of-thrones-piracy-is-a-compliment .
Jude: I mean that some television producers are having a clue about piracy.
Jude: I think the MPAA is likely going to follow the lead of the RIAA and endorse the Internet.
Jude: well, there's still a long way to go with even music online.
cheeseduck: ah, that. MAking slow progress in it.
cheeseduck: I thought it was a book *I* was writing.
Lately, I've been writing books and screenplays and stuff more than I've been reading them. :-D
"I've been reading a lot of scripts lately." "You know, it's cheaper than going to the movies."
cheeseduck: some people find the screenplays funny as they are.
I always found the standard they are supposed to be written in weird.
cheeseduck: for other people, it ruins the experience.
I see rindolf, did you catch the walking dead's finale?
cheeseduck: I have something of my own - http://www.shlomifish.org/open-source/projects/XML-Grammar/Fiction/
Jude: horror drama - I have a soft stomach.
Jude: I prefer humour or drama/humour or sci-fi/humour or sci-fi/humour/drama or stuff like that.
k, sorry to have bothered you
Jude: I watched three episodes of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic, and so far - I'm game.
Jude: you did not bother me.
Jude: do you watch My Little Pony?
Jude: ah, I love it so far.
heard it can get quite rough
more nudity and violence than spartacus and game of thrones combined
One episode involved a lot of songs, which I disliked.
Jude: it's directed at little girls.
Jude: so it's a pretty clean show.
Jude: if you want incest and violence, then look no further than the Jewish bible.
there are a lot of dubbing sections of the show to go with metal songs or violent scripts etc
Jude: reportedly, it was quite realism then (the Bible I mean).
Jude: ah, nice. So am I.
I have to go watch game of thrones
Jude: yes, you need to process the Bible a lot to get to the good stuff.
will talk to you in an hour
yeah, in Israel we have to take bible classes
Maybe I'll prepare a fortune out of this conversation.
Jude: I live in Tel Aviv.
don't tell me you live near rabin sq.
Jude: well, I teach stuff via blogging and Internet writing.
Jude: no, but I go there often.
Jude: no, I just live with my parents.
Jude: I graduated from EE from the Technion.
Jude: a good old fashioned Web 1.0 site in modern clothing.
Like valid HTML, modern CSS, some JS enhancements, etc.
I have some blogs on livejournal.com/etc.
do you know a guy called nimrod?
Jude: there are many people called Nimrod - it's a common name.
don't want to give him in on public chat
Jude: not sure I know a Nimrod off hand.
Jude: OK, feel free to PM.
Jude: many Israeli names can get confusing.
Jude: I can easily come to Rabin sq. - there's a bus there from here.
he's my brother, he lives close to you and he's also an open-source enthusaist
I take them to uni on a daily basis
I live right by rabin sq.
Jude: so you study in TAU?
Jude: TAU has tons of hot chicks.
Jude: there aren't a lot of people on the streets of Gimmel.
I know one or two nice looking girls, but I usually get put off by their personalities
Jude: I think maths is taught wrong in several aspects.
I've only been attracted to one specimen of the female sex ever
I dunno, I agree when you speak of highschool maths
I like university maths so far
Jude: well, there are a lot of girls studying more humane stuff.
I generally don't like people who study humane subjects (I don't consider philosophy to be as such though)
Jude: I've made a transition from a mathematician to a software developer and now I'm more of a writer/entertainer/amateur-philosopher.
you didn't like the way it was taught?
Jude: well: 1. No pairwise work. Big mistake.
2. Need to memorise a lot of silly stuff. Why??
3. Maybe allow some sloppiness. Make maths more humane.
maths can't afford to be sloppy
There's something poetical about many maths' proofs.
that's why you have to be really strict
Jude: yes, that's why I think we should now move into proof verifier realm.
if you want your proof to be valid
Jude: but I was once criticised for this - http://ladypine.livejournal.com/24574.html
Jude: thing is - not everything should be strict when teaching.
Jude: I agree that mathematical intuition can be misleading, but it's still a good thing to have.
Jude: thing is I think many mathematicians now require a lot of dedication and selling their soul to the devil, which is turning them into http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captain_Nemo -s.
it's not a very formal proof
Jude: when I studied EE most of my courses were with open material, and I could do pairwise work, which I enjoyed.
that the concept is more important than the formalization
but a lot of my professors agree with you
and would give much more attention to grasping the important concept, and understanding intuition behind proofs
Jude: I'm always right. Unless I claim that "A is not-A". But Chuck Norris would be right even then.
Hah! A new Chuck Norris factoid.
it's been nice chatting with you, I really have to go now, I need to watch GoT and then go to bed and wake up in 4 hours
Jude: my father and I now have an ongoing Chuck Norris meme.
Jude: bye, have fun, and good night.
Jude: well, we say stuff like "you're my most Chuck Norris dad." or "I taught Chuck Norris how to fight."
I'm not close enough to any member of my family
rindolf: Douglas Hofstadter gave a talk about how mathematicians aren't as rigorous as they claim to be
and that they use a lot of analogical thinking
it was at the university of Toronto
but I can basically tell you what he said more or less
not sure if it can be accessed still
<+Nisstyre-laptop> but if you read either GEB or I Am a Strange Loop you'll get it
Nisstyre-laptop: GEB was a nice book, but I knew a lot of what he was saying there.
Nisstyre-laptop: I still enjoyed the drama stuff in the middle with Achilles, the Tortoise and their friends.
rindolf: you had the idea of using PM as a metaphor for systems of thinking and the mind?
because that's what the book is about
the formal system constructed by Russell and Whitehead
Nisstyre-laptop: I didn't think of it.
the entire book is his theory of consciousness
and how there are levels of thinking
Nisstyre-laptop: well, I read "I think, therefore I laugh" before I read GEB.
you can be less of a thinking being, etc...
Yes, he says that consciousness requires thinking in loops, or self-reflection.
Well, it's an informal theory of consciousness.
it requires what he calls a strange loop
and there can be many levels to it
more levels == what we think of as more human or more conscious beings
so PM actually is able to self reflect to an extent
although it requires a human to interpret it

I believe, that creating artificial intelligence/artificial consciousness won't be easy to do, will require a lot of complex code, and will likely be faulty (have its own will, make mistakes, not run as quickly as more specialised code, etc.).
depends what you mean by AI
the first human like robot will be build in japan, the first artifical intelligence in the us
the church-turing hypothesis would seem to imply it's possible, at least in principle
although I intensely dislike that term
since it tries to say that any system of thinking that doesn't work exactly the same as a human one isn't AI
you guys are all worried about intelligence, I think that will be the easy part. Then comes the important stuff: giving it a sense of humor.

so there was the idea that consciousness is associated with information flow, and that "more" information flow is "More" consciousness, a continuum like gravity... but gravity can produce a qualitatively different effect past a certain level (black holes..)
so the "loop" is where information flow becomes qualitatively different ?
it would be the ability a system has to observe itself, and encode the system itself in the system
I don't know many people who can be truly accused of having their own thoughts
i dont thinkso but i have some related quotes from somewhere
but can a system only approximate itself
you can encode formulas in PM as formulas in PM
what is that supposed to mean?
nature has many 'feedback loops' involving information
physical limitations result in a hard limit of feedback loops
if you point a camera at a mirror eventually it will "stop"
but the sequel is more clear on what it's about
doomlord: anyway, if you nest implementations of a computer in a computer eventually there will be a limit imposed by the physical situation
i.e. the memory and processor speed
it's like entropy, only for people who are afraid to think :P
but dont physical systems also have practical limitations
yes but those are not what we imagine them to be
if only we knew the meaning of life, that would make things so much easier

I think the whole "AIs spawning AIs" dream is not a good strategy for doing software dev. I think programming is here to stay. It's not like humans can efficiently do what a dedicated polynomial time program can.
that new immortality project had some interesting videos
doomlord: a large part of human technology is mental.
doomlord: in fact, we can no longer survive without our mental technology. We couldn't for thousands of years.
gde33: you can survive without your mental technology? Even without conceptual thought?
isn't that what all the other species do?
i saw some TED talk trying to explain the difference between chinese and western spending/saving habits in the way the language encourages people to think about time
supposedly chinese language makes it harder to think of past,present,future seperately
all languages have the word "argument" but some want it to have aditional meanings, I believe in china an argument is equal to disobedience. lol
in english it is a kind of fight
争 is a dispute 争论 is an argument or debate
I cant think of good examples, I used to know a girl who knew many languages
she showed me how some things are badly broken in some languages
is it true japanese can't say "no", they have to repeat the question in negative..
thats what we were told when learning but they must have a word for no surely
doomlord: there is "Hai" for Yes and "iie" for no
so its just impolite to say "no" i guess
doomlord: in English you don't repeat
gde33: depends on the person... my mother and father thought nothing of explaining politeness to me and will happilly talk overtop me when I am speaking
gde33: I only know (Modern) Hebrew, English, some mostly forgotten Written Arabic, and some French (which I'm now trying to regain).
I have also run into the same from Chinese, Japanese, American, European AND African people I have met
gde33: well, I also know bits of other languages like Spanish, Russian, German, etc.
gde33: I know that in Hebrew we have compulsive genders for objects, so we don't care about phrasing sentences in a gender-neutral form, which is an English obsession.
gde33: I think it is parodied in this book - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skinny_Legs_and_All_%28novel%29 (great one, BTW - taught me a lot).
heh languages with sexism built in.. gender all the way through
some languages are also more emotional than others
so much enthusiasm it makes you think something is going on
gde33: spoken or written and the correct manner for if you are addressing "up/peer/down" the social ladder with regards respect... yes
Belxjander: does that apply to many words?
